segment.source: Getting started: Creating a project
segment.target: Getting started: Creating a project

segment.source: \[ Updated for UWP apps on Windows 10.
segment.target: \[ Updated for UWP apps on Windows 10.

segment.source: For Windows 8.x articles, see the archive \]
segment.target: For Windows 8.x articles, see the archive \]

segment.source: Creating a project
segment.target: Creating a project

segment.source: Microsoft Visual Studio is to Windows as Xcode is to iOS and Mac OS.
segment.target: Microsoft Visual Studio is to Windows as Xcode is to iOS and Mac OS.

segment.source: In this walkthrough, we help you get comfortable using Visual Studio.
segment.target: In this walkthrough, we help you get comfortable using Visual Studio.

segment.source: It shows you the absolute basics you'll need to know to get started.
segment.target: It shows you the absolute basics you'll need to know to get started.

segment.source: Each time you create an app, you'll follow steps similar to these.
segment.target: Each time you create an app, you'll follow steps similar to these.

segment.source: The following video compares Xcode and Visual Studio.
segment.target: The following video compares Xcode and Visual Studio.

segment.source: Creating an app for Windows 10 (more formally referred to as a Universal Windows Platform (UWP) app) is rather like creating an iOS app using Storyboard.
segment.target: Creating an app for Windows 10 (more formally referred to as a Universal Windows Platform (UWP) app) is rather like creating an iOS app using Storyboard.

segment.source: The Windows 10 app is often constructed over several pages, each page containing a different part of the user interface, like a web site.
segment.target: The Windows 10 app is often constructed over several pages, each page containing a different part of the user interface, like a web site.

segment.source: Each page has two associated source files: one to store the user interface defined either programmatically or visually, stored in XAML overview format, and one that contains the source code.
segment.target: Each page has two associated source files: one to store the user interface defined either programmatically or visually, stored in XAML overview format, and one that contains the source code.

segment.source: As your user interacts with your app, they will navigate between these pages.
segment.target: As your user interacts with your app, they will navigate between these pages.

segment.source: In this walkthrough, you will create an app with two pages.
segment.target: In this walkthrough, you will create an app with two pages.

segment.source: Note An important feature of Windows 10 apps is the fact that the same source code, and the same API set, is available to you no matter the platform.
segment.target: Note An important feature of Windows 10 apps is the fact that the same source code, and the same API set, is available to you no matter the platform.

segment.source: As you know, when you are writing a universal iOS app for iPhone and iPad, you can determine at run-time which platform your app is running on, and take the appropriate action.
segment.target: As you know, when you are writing a universal iOS app for iPhone and iPad, you can determine at run-time which platform your app is running on, and take the appropriate action.

segment.source: In a similar way, Windows 10 apps can tell, at run-time, the device they are running on.
segment.target: In a similar way, Windows 10 apps can tell, at run-time, the device they are running on.

segment.source: With a UWP app, there is no need to use \#ifdef's in your source code to create phone versus desktop builds.
segment.target: With a UWP app, there is no need to use \#ifdef's in your source code to create phone versus desktop builds.

segment.source: Conveniently, Windows 10 apps also intelligently use their user interface controls depending on the device: for example, your app may reference a date picker control, and the control will automatically look and function differently depending on whether it's running on a desktop or a phone screen.
segment.target: Conveniently, Windows 10 apps also intelligently use their user interface controls depending on the device: for example, your app may reference a date picker control, and the control will automatically look and function differently depending on whether it's running on a desktop or a phone screen.

segment.source: Your source code, however, remains the same.
segment.target: Your source code, however, remains the same.

segment.source: Let's see how we can create a Windows 10 app.
segment.target: Let's see how we can create a Windows 10 app.

segment.source: Start by running Visual Studio.
segment.target: Start by running Visual Studio.

segment.source: The first time you run it, Visual Studio will ask you to get a developer license.
segment.target: The first time you run it, Visual Studio will ask you to get a developer license.

segment.source: A developer license lets you install and test Windows Store apps on your local computer before you submit them to the Windows Store.
segment.target: A developer license lets you install and test Windows Store apps on your local computer before you submit them to the Windows Store.

segment.source: To get a license, follow the on-screen directions to sign in with a Microsoft account.
segment.target: To get a license, follow the on-screen directions to sign in with a Microsoft account.

segment.source: If you don't have one, click the Sign up link in the Developer License dialog box, and follow the on-screen directions.
segment.target: If you don't have one, click the Sign up link in the Developer License dialog box, and follow the on-screen directions.

segment.source: For comparison, when you start Xcode, the first thing you see is the Welcome to Xcode screen, similar to the following figure.
segment.target: For comparison, when you start Xcode, the first thing you see is the Welcome to Xcode screen, similar to the following figure.

segment.source: Visual Studio is very similar.
segment.target: Visual Studio is very similar.

segment.source: You'll see the Start Page, as shown in the following figure.
segment.target: You'll see the Start Page, as shown in the following figure.

segment.source: To create a new app, start by making a project by doing one of the following:
segment.target: To create a new app, start by making a project by doing one of the following:

segment.source: In the Start area, tap New Project.
segment.target: In the Start area, tap New Project.

segment.source: Tap the File menu, and then tap New Project.
segment.target: Tap the File menu, and then tap New Project.

segment.source: For comparison, when you create a new project in Xcode, you see a list of project templates like those shown in the following figure.
segment.target: For comparison, when you create a new project in Xcode, you see a list of project templates like those shown in the following figure.

segment.source: In Visual Studio, there are also several project templates to choose from, as shown in the following figure.
segment.target: In Visual Studio, there are also several project templates to choose from, as shown in the following figure.

source.pc: visual studio new project dialog box

target.pc: visual studio new project dialog box

segment.source: For this walkthrough, tap Visual C\#, and then tap Windows, Windows Universal and Blank App (Windows Universal).
segment.target: For this walkthrough, tap Visual C\#, and then tap Windows, Windows Universal and Blank App (Windows Universal).

segment.source: In the Name box, type "MyApp", and then tap OK.
segment.target: In the Name box, type "MyApp", and then tap OK.

segment.source: Visual Studio creates and then displays your first project.
segment.target: Visual Studio creates and then displays your first project.

segment.source: Now, you can begin to design your app and add code to it.
segment.target: Now, you can begin to design your app and add code to it.

segment.source: Next step
segment.target: Next step
